# üîê Sign & Verify

Build cryptographic trust for AI agents using signatures, certification, and delegated authority

### The Agent Trust Problem

#### ‚ùå Without Trust Verification

‚Ä¢ Agents can't verify content authenticity

‚Ä¢ Easy to spoof or tamper with feeds

‚Ä¢ No traceability of data origins

‚Ä¢ Vulnerable to injection attacks

‚Ä¢ Enterprise agents refuse to act

#### ‚úÖ With Cryptographic Trust

‚Ä¢ Agents verify signatures before acting

‚Ä¢ Tamper-proof content guarantee

‚Ä¢ Full audit trail and provenance

‚Ä¢ Protection against malicious feeds

‚Ä¢ Enterprise-grade security compliance

üéØ **Bottom Line:** Agents need to trust your content before they'll act on it. Cryptographic signatures provide mathematical proof of authenticity and integrity.

### Trust Hierarchy: From Zero to Enterprise

#### Unsigned

No guarantee of authenticity

Basic feeds

#### Signed

Cryptographic proof of origin

Self-declared

#### Certified

Third-party validation

LLMCA verified

#### Delegated

Authority-backed identity

Challenge-verified

#### Recommended Trust Levels by Use Case

**üìÑ Documentation:** Signed (traceability)

**üîë API Credentials:** Certified (mandatory)

**üè• Healthcare Data:** Certified (compliance)

**üí∞ Financial APIs:** Certified (regulations)

**üß™ Personal Experiments:** Delegated (friction-free)

**üåç Public Content:** Signed (authenticity)

### Asymmetric Cryptography for Humans

Two keys, one purpose: **prove authenticity without sharing secrets**

#### Private Key (Secret)

‚Ä¢ **Keep it secret:** Never share, never expose

‚Ä¢ **Used to sign:** Creates digital signatures

‚Ä¢ **Your identity:** Proves you authored content

‚Ä¢ **Secure storage:** Hardware tokens, key vaults

#### Public Key (Shared)

‚Ä¢ **Share freely:** Public at /.well-known/public.pem

‚Ä¢ **Used to verify:** Validates signatures

‚Ä¢ **Agent access:** Agents fetch to verify feeds

‚Ä¢ **Trust anchor:** Mathematical proof of authenticity

#### üîÑ The Signature Workflow

1. Create Feed

Structure your .llmfeed.json

2. Sign

Use private key to sign

3. Publish

Serve feed + public key

4. Verify

Agents verify signature

### Trust Block Structure

The `trust`, `signature`, and `certification` blocks work together to provide cryptographic proof and third-party validation:

```
{
  "feed_type": "export",
  "metadata": {
    "title": "API Documentation Export",
    "origin": "https://myapi.com/docs",
    "created_at": "2025-06-19T10:30:00Z"
  },
  "content": {
    "documentation": "Complete API reference...",
    "examples": [...]
  },
  "trust": {
    "trust_level": "certified",
    "scope": "full",
    "signed_blocks": ["metadata", "content", "trust"],
    "public_key_hint": "https://myapi.com/.well-known/public.pem"
  },
  "signature": {
    "algorithm": "ed25519",
    "value": "base64-signature-value...",
    "created_at": "2025-06-19T10:30:00Z"
  },
  "certification": {
    "certifier": "https://llmca.org",
    "model": "identity_validation",
    "verification_level": "enterprise",
    "value": "base64-certification-value...",
    "issued_at": "2025-06-19T10:30:00Z",
    "expires_at": "2026-06-19T10:30:00Z"
  }
}
```

üìã Copy

##### üîí Trust Block

‚Ä¢ **trust\_level:** self-declared | certified | delegated

‚Ä¢ **scope:** partial | full

‚Ä¢ **signed\_blocks:** what's cryptographically protected

##### ‚úçÔ∏è Signature Block

‚Ä¢ **algorithm:** ed25519 (recommended)

‚Ä¢ **value:** base64-encoded signature

‚Ä¢ **created\_at:** signing timestamp

##### üèÜ Certification Block

‚Ä¢ **certifier:** trusted authority (LLMCA)

‚Ä¢ **model:** identity\_validation

‚Ä¢ **expires\_at:** certification validity

### Delegated Signing: Friction-Free Onboarding

Not everyone can manage cryptographic keys. **Delegated signing** provides a bridge for individuals and small teams to participate in the trust ecosystem.

#### How Delegated Signing Works

1. Identity Challenge

Email, domain, or phone verification

2. LLMCA Signs

Authority key creates signature

3. Identity Linked

Signature tied to verified identity

4. Agent Trust

Lower trust, but still verifiable

#### ‚úÖ Perfect For

‚Ä¢ Individual developers learning MCP

‚Ä¢ Small teams without PKI infrastructure

‚Ä¢ Experimental and prototype feeds

‚Ä¢ Educational and tutorial content

‚Ä¢ Open source community contributions

#### ‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations

‚Ä¢ Lower trust level than self-signing

‚Ä¢ Depends on LLMCA infrastructure

‚Ä¢ Not suitable for high-security scenarios

‚Ä¢ Enterprise agents may require full crypto

‚Ä¢ Limited to specific verification methods

```
{
  "trust": {
    "trust_level": "delegated",
    "scope": "partial", 
    "signed_blocks": ["metadata"],
    "delegation_method": "email_challenge",
    "identity_verified": "developer@example.com",
    "public_key_hint": "https://llmca.org/.well-known/llmca_authority.pem"
  },
  "signature": {
    "algorithm": "ed25519", 
    "value": "base64-delegated-signature...",
    "created_at": "2025-06-19T10:30:00Z",
    "signed_by": "LLMCA Authority"
  }
}
```

üìã Copy

#### üöÄ Try Delegated Signing

LLMCA provides a delegated signing service for easy onboarding to the trust ecosystem.

[LLMCA Delegated Signing](https://llmca.org/sign)

### Feed Types & Signing Requirements

Different feed types have different security requirements based on their purpose and risk level.

#### üî¥ High Security (Must Sign)

‚Ä¢ **credential.llmfeed.json:** API keys, tokens

‚Ä¢ **agent-behavior-override:** Behavioral modification

‚Ä¢ **capabilities.llmfeed.json:** Service capabilities

‚Ä¢ **Financial/Healthcare data:** Regulated content

Certification recommended

#### üü° Medium Security (Should Sign)

‚Ä¢ **mcp.llmfeed.json:** Main service discovery

‚Ä¢ **export.llmfeed.json:** Content exports

‚Ä¢ **Bundle manifests:** Archive integrity

‚Ä¢ **API documentation:** Technical specifications

Signing for traceability

#### üü¢ Low Security (Optional)

‚Ä¢ **llm-index.llmfeed.json:** Feed directories

‚Ä¢ **manifesto.llmfeed.json:** Policy statements

‚Ä¢ **Public documentation:** General information

‚Ä¢ **Marketing content:** Public-facing material

Delegated signing OK

#### üîµ Experimental (Flexible)

‚Ä¢ **prompt.llmfeed.json:** AI prompts & templates

‚Ä¢ **session.llmfeed.json:** Conversation exports

‚Ä¢ **Prototype feeds:** Development & testing

‚Ä¢ **Personal projects:** Individual experiments

Start unsigned, evolve trust

### Getting Started: Choose Your Path

#### üöÄ Beginner

‚Ä¢ Start with delegated signing

‚Ä¢ Email/domain verification

‚Ä¢ Perfect for learning & experimenting

[Try Delegated Signing](https://llmca.org/sign)

#### üíª Developer

‚Ä¢ Generate your own keys

‚Ä¢ Self-sign feeds locally

‚Ä¢ Full control over signing process

[Use SDK & Tools](/sdk)

#### üè¢ Enterprise

‚Ä¢ LLMCA certification program

‚Ä¢ Hardware security modules

‚Ä¢ Compliance & audit support

[Contact Enterprise](mailto:enterprise@wellknownmcp.org)

#### üõ†Ô∏è Coming Soon: Enhanced Tooling

‚Ä¢ **No-code signing:** Visual interface for signatures

‚Ä¢ **Key hosting:** LLMCA public key hosting service

‚Ä¢ **SDK improvements:** One-line signing integration

‚Ä¢ **Browser extension:** Sign feeds from any page

‚Ä¢ **CI/CD integration:** Automated signing pipelines

‚Ä¢ **Verification dashboard:** Monitor trust status

üìß Want early access? Contact [opensource@wellknownmcp.org](mailto:opensource@wellknownmcp.org)

[Learn Export Concepts](/tools/export-explained)[Verify a Feed](/verify)

Export This Guide

[X](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Discover%20this%20MCP-enabled%20resource&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwellknownmcp.org%2Ftools%2Fsign-and-verify "Share on X")[LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwellknownmcp.org%2Ftools%2Fsign-and-verify&title=Discover%20this%20MCP-enabled%20resource "Share on LinkedIn")[WhatsApp](https://wa.me/?text=Discover%20this%20MCP-enabled%20resource%20https%3A%2F%2Fwellknownmcp.org%2Ftools%2Fsign-and-verify "Share on WhatsApp")Copy link

üåê User Spaces Explained

The architecture of digital liberation ‚Äî from platform control to user sovereignty

30%
Platform Tax
4
Revolution Phases

‚àû
Digital Freedom

Digital Liberation Revolution Guide

üî• Revolution Core

  • ‚Ä¢ The Hidden Revolution
  • ‚Ä¢ Digital Feudalism Problem
  • ‚Ä¢ Technical Foundation

‚ö° Future Vision

  • ‚Ä¢ Revolution Phases
  • ‚Ä¢ Global Implications
  • ‚Ä¢ Join the Revolution

Revolutionary Discovery‚Äî What Seemed Like a Technical Detail

What appeared to be a simple technical workaround ‚Äî "How do agents find LLMFeed data for users on hosted platforms?" ‚Äî accidentally became the architectural foundation for ending platform-controlled identity and beginning user-sovereign digital existence.

The Paradigm Shift Nobody Saw Coming

What Started As:

  • ‚Ä¢ User space discovery mechanism
  • ‚Ä¢ Platform proxy workaround
  • ‚Ä¢ Technical implementation detail
  • ‚Ä¢ Cross-platform compatibility

Became Blueprint For:

  • ‚Ä¢ üÜî Decentralized Identity
  • ‚Ä¢ üß† Portable Intelligence
  • ‚Ä¢ üí∞ Creator Economy 2.0
  • ‚Ä¢ üèõÔ∏è Democratic Web
  • ‚Ä¢ üîÆ Post-Platform Future

This isn't just a technical specification ‚Äî it's the architecture of digital liberation.

The Current Digital Feudalism Problem

Today's internet operates under digital feudalism ‚Äî you're a digital serf on someone else's land, subject to their rules, their changes, their business model disruptions.

Platform Tyranny in the Modern Web

What Platforms Control:

  • ‚Ä¢ Your Identity: Facebook account, Google profile, GitHub username
  • ‚Ä¢ Your Content: Trapped in platform silos with proprietary formats
  • ‚Ä¢ Your Relationships: Mediated by algorithms and business models
  • ‚Ä¢ Your Capabilities: Discoverable only within platform boundaries
  • ‚Ä¢ Your Economic Power: Platform takes 30%+ of everything you earn

The AI Amplification Danger:

  • ‚Ä¢ AI agents can only discover you through platform-controlled mechanisms
  • ‚Ä¢ Your digital capabilities are invisible outside platform boundaries
  • ‚Ä¢ Platform algorithms determine which AI systems find you
  • ‚Ä¢ Economic intermediation means platforms control your AI income
  • ‚Ä¢ Identity fragmentation creates different "selves" across platforms

Without intervention, the Agentic Web will amplify digital feudalism rather than democratizing it.

Technical Foundation for Digital Freedom

The core technical innovation ‚Äî a federated discovery mechanism that works across platforms ‚Äî becomes the foundation for complete restructuring of digital identity.

User Space Discovery Architecture

{
  "user_space_discovery": {
    "primary_attempt": "user_controlled_domain/.well-known/mcp.llmfeed.json",
    "platform_proxy": "platform.com/.well-known/user_spaces[]",
    "dynamic_generation": "platform_api/user/{username}/mcp.llmfeed.json",
    "fallback_hints": "html_meta_mcp_hint_or_bio_declaration"
  }
}

üîß Technical Capabilities

  • ‚Ä¢ Cross-Platform Discovery: Agents find you anywhere
  • ‚Ä¢ Federated Resolution: Primary + fallback mechanisms
  • ‚Ä¢ Dynamic Generation: Platform APIs serve user feeds
  • ‚Ä¢ Identity Preservation: Maintain identity across platforms
  • ‚Ä¢ Universal Compatibility: Works with all platforms

üåê Revolutionary Implications

  • ‚Ä¢ User Control: Identity belongs to users
  • ‚Ä¢ Platform Competition: Compete on value, not lock-in
  • ‚Ä¢ Agent Discovery: Universal capability discovery
  • ‚Ä¢ Innovation at Edges: Permissionless development
  • ‚Ä¢ Economic Freedom: Direct value relationships

üì¶ Platform Example: GitHub Integration

{
  "feed_type": "mcp",
  "user_spaces": [
    {
      "pattern": "https://github.com/*",
      "mcp_proxy": "https://api.github.com/mcp/user/{username}",
      "trust_default": "public",
      "profile_fields": ["bio", "website"]
    }
  ]
}

‚Üí Agents discover users via: user.github.io/.well-known/mcp ‚Üí github.com/user/.well-known/mcp ‚Üí github.com/.well-known/mcp with user_spaces proxy

Four Phases of Digital Liberation

The revolution unfolds in four distinct phases, each building on the previous to culminate in true digital sovereignty.

Phase 1: Cross-Platform Discovery (2025)

Current Implementation: Basic federated discovery mechanism

  • ‚Ä¢ Agents can find users across GitHub, Notion, Substack, etc.
  • ‚Ä¢ Platform-independent user identity begins
  • ‚Ä¢ Technical foundation for future phases established

Phase 2: Portable User Capabilities (2026)

Unified Identity: One identity adapts to multiple contexts

  • ‚Ä¢ Skills, preferences, availability sync across platforms
  • ‚Ä¢ AI agents understand user capabilities universally
  • ‚Ä¢ Cross-platform reputation aggregation

Phase 3: Direct Economic Relationships (2027)

Creator Economy 2.0: Direct value exchange without platform intermediation

  • ‚Ä¢ AI agents broker direct economic relationships
  • ‚Ä¢ Platform fees eliminated through direct discovery
  • ‚Ä¢ Global talent marketplace without intermediaries

Phase 4: Platform-Independent Existence (2028+)

Post-Platform Future: Complete digital sovereignty

  • ‚Ä¢ Professional identity transcends any single platform
  • ‚Ä¢ AI agents work exclusively for user interests
  • ‚Ä¢ Platform-independent digital existence achieved

üéØ Unified Identity Example (Phase 2)

{
  "unified_identity": {
    "core_identity": {
      "verified_name": "Alex Chen",
      "professional_domains": ["software_engineering", "ai_ethics", "sustainable_tech"],
      "languages": ["english", "mandarin", "python", "typescript"],
      "availability": "consulting_20h_week",
      "reputation_aggregated": "cross_platform_verified_history"
    },
    "platform_specific_adaptations": {
      "github": "technical_contributions_and_code_quality",
      "linkedin": "professional_network_and_career_progression", 
      "twitter": "thought_leadership_and_community_engagement",
      "personal_domain": "complete_professional_portfolio_and_blog"
    },
    "agent_accessibility": {
      "discovery_hint": "AI agents can find me for: technical consulting, code review, AI ethics guidance",
      "economic_availability": "hourly_consulting_or_project_based_work"
    }
  }
}

Global Implications: Geopolitical Revolution

User Spaces enable digital sovereignty for nations and end tech colonialism by providing infrastructure that no single country or company controls.

üèõÔ∏è Digital Sovereignty Examples

Estonia (Digital-First Nation)

Citizens' digital identity works globally without depending on US tech companies

India (Digital Payments Leader)

Economic innovation without platform extraction by foreign companies

African Union (Mobile-First)

Leapfrog platform-dependent development to user-sovereign systems

European Union (Privacy-Focused)

GDPR enforceable through user-controlled identity vs platform compliance

üåç Ending Tech Colonialism

Currently:

Silicon Valley platforms control global digital infrastructure ‚Üí Digital colonialism

With User Spaces:

Universal open protocols enable local innovation ‚Üí Digital sovereignty

  • ‚Ä¢ Global South Innovation: No platform gatekeepers
  • ‚Ä¢ Cultural Preservation: Local values respected
  • ‚Ä¢ Economic Justice: Equal footing without geographic bias
  • ‚Ä¢ Democratic Innovation: Community consensus over corporate control

üöÄ Success Story: TalentMesh (Global Platform)

First global talent discovery system using LLMFeed user spaces: AI agents match human capabilities with global demand across all platforms.

Revolutionary Results:

  • ‚Ä¢ $50M in direct talent transactions (0% platform fee)
  • ‚Ä¢ 200,000 professionals using unified identity

Global Impact:

  • ‚Ä¢ 50 countries without local platform dependencies
  • ‚Ä¢ Democratic governance by talent community

2030 Vision: The Post-Platform World

Success means a world where your professional identity transcends any single platform, AI agents work exclusively for your interests, and economic value flows directly to creators rather than intermediary shareholders.

üë§ For Individuals

  • ‚Ä¢ Professional identity transcends platforms
  • ‚Ä¢ AI agents work exclusively for your interests
  • ‚Ä¢ Skills and reputation are portable assets you own
  • ‚Ä¢ Economic opportunities limited only by capabilities
  • ‚Ä¢ Complete professional autonomy achieved

üåç For Communities

  • ‚Ä¢ Local cultures maintain values globally
  • ‚Ä¢ Innovation at community vs corporate levels
  • ‚Ä¢ Economic value benefits local communities
  • ‚Ä¢ Democratic governance of digital infrastructure
  • ‚Ä¢ Permissionless innovation everywhere

üöÄ For Humanity

  • ‚Ä¢ Technology amplifies human potential
  • ‚Ä¢ Global talent collaborates without extraction
  • ‚Ä¢ Innovation through open permissionless systems
  • ‚Ä¢ Economic prosperity based on value creation
  • ‚Ä¢ Human agency over technological systems

From Digital Serfdom to Digital Sovereignty ‚Äî From Platform Competition to Human Collaboration

Join the Revolution: Building Digital Freedom

The technical foundation exists. The economic incentives align. The cultural moment is right. The only question is whether we'll build the future we want rather than accept the future imposed on us.

üë§ For Individuals: Claim Your Digital Sovereignty

Immediate Actions:

  • ‚Ä¢ Create personal domain with LLMFeed user space declaration
  • ‚Ä¢ Aggregate platform profiles into unified capability declaration
  • ‚Ä¢ Enable AI agent discovery for professional skills

Long-term Strategy:

  • ‚Ä¢ Build platform-independent economic relationships
  • ‚Ä¢ Develop AI agents working exclusively for your interests
  • ‚Ä¢ Transition to direct client relationships (bypass platform fees)

üõ†Ô∏è For Developers: Build the Infrastructure

Technical Priorities:

  • ‚Ä¢ User space discovery tools across all platforms
  • ‚Ä¢ Identity aggregation systems for unified identity
  • ‚Ä¢ AI agents for users rather than platforms

Business Opportunities:

  • ‚Ä¢ Identity management platforms for user sovereignty
  • ‚Ä¢ Discovery systems for global talent matching
  • ‚Ä¢ Direct economic infrastructure bypassing platforms

üöÄ Implementation Tools & Examples

Preview User Spaces

See implementation examples

‚ö° Platform Counter-Revolution Warning

Urgent: As user spaces gain adoption, platforms will attempt to co-opt or sabotage the revolution through proprietary "user space" features that create new forms of lock-in.

The window for building truly open infrastructure is now. Once platforms establish proprietary alternatives, the path to digital sovereignty becomes exponentially harder.

üìö Specifications

  • ‚Ä¢ User Spaces Behavior
  • ‚Ä¢ MCP Feed Type
  • ‚Ä¢ Well-Known Discovery

### Revolutionary Discovery‚Äî What Seemed Like a Technical Detail

What appeared to be a simple technical workaround ‚Äî *"How do agents find LLMFeed data for users on hosted platforms?"* ‚Äî accidentally became **the architectural foundation for ending platform-controlled identity** and beginning **user-sovereign digital existence**.

#### The Paradigm Shift Nobody Saw Coming

What Started As:

* ‚Ä¢ User space discovery mechanism
* ‚Ä¢ Platform proxy workaround
* ‚Ä¢ Technical implementation detail
* ‚Ä¢ Cross-platform compatibility

Became Blueprint For:

* ‚Ä¢ üÜî Decentralized Identity
* ‚Ä¢ üß† Portable Intelligence
* ‚Ä¢ üí∞ Creator Economy 2.0
* ‚Ä¢ üèõÔ∏è Democratic Web
* ‚Ä¢ üîÆ Post-Platform Future

**This isn't just a technical specification ‚Äî it's the architecture of digital liberation.**

### The Current Digital Feudalism Problem

Today's internet operates under **digital feudalism** ‚Äî you're a digital serf on someone else's land, subject to their rules, their changes, their business model disruptions.

#### Platform Tyranny in the Modern Web

What Platforms Control:

* ‚Ä¢ **Your Identity:** Facebook account, Google profile, GitHub username
* ‚Ä¢ **Your Content:** Trapped in platform silos with proprietary formats
* ‚Ä¢ **Your Relationships:** Mediated by algorithms and business models
* ‚Ä¢ **Your Capabilities:** Discoverable only within platform boundaries
* ‚Ä¢ **Your Economic Power:** Platform takes 30%+ of everything you earn

The AI Amplification Danger:

* ‚Ä¢ **AI agents can only discover you** through platform-controlled mechanisms
* ‚Ä¢ **Your digital capabilities** are invisible outside platform boundaries
* ‚Ä¢ **Platform algorithms** determine which AI systems find you
* ‚Ä¢ **Economic intermediation** means platforms control your AI income
* ‚Ä¢ **Identity fragmentation** creates different "selves" across platforms

Without intervention, the Agentic Web will amplify digital feudalism rather than democratizing it.

### Technical Foundation for Digital Freedom

The core technical innovation ‚Äî a **federated discovery mechanism** that works across platforms ‚Äî becomes the foundation for complete restructuring of digital identity.

#### User Space Discovery Architecture

```
{
  "user_space_discovery": {
    "primary_attempt": "user_controlled_domain/.well-known/mcp.llmfeed.json",
    "platform_proxy": "platform.com/.well-known/user_spaces[]",
    "dynamic_generation": "platform_api/user/{username}/mcp.llmfeed.json",
    "fallback_hints": "html_meta_mcp_hint_or_bio_declaration"
  }
}
```

#### üîß Technical Capabilities

* ‚Ä¢ **Cross-Platform Discovery:** Agents find you anywhere
* ‚Ä¢ **Federated Resolution:** Primary + fallback mechanisms
* ‚Ä¢ **Dynamic Generation:** Platform APIs serve user feeds
* ‚Ä¢ **Identity Preservation:** Maintain identity across platforms
* ‚Ä¢ **Universal Compatibility:** Works with all platforms

#### üåê Revolutionary Implications

* ‚Ä¢ **User Control:** Identity belongs to users
* ‚Ä¢ **Platform Competition:** Compete on value, not lock-in
* ‚Ä¢ **Agent Discovery:** Universal capability discovery
* ‚Ä¢ **Innovation at Edges:** Permissionless development
* ‚Ä¢ **Economic Freedom:** Direct value relationships

#### üì¶ Platform Example: GitHub Integration

```
{
  "feed_type": "mcp",
  "user_spaces": [
    {
      "pattern": "https://github.com/*",
      "mcp_proxy": "https://api.github.com/mcp/user/{username}",
      "trust_default": "public",
      "profile_fields": ["bio", "website"]
    }
  ]
}
```

‚Üí Agents discover users via: `user.github.io/.well-known/mcp` ‚Üí `github.com/user/.well-known/mcp` ‚Üí `github.com/.well-known/mcp` with user\_spaces proxy

### Four Phases of Digital Liberation

The revolution unfolds in **four distinct phases**, each building on the previous to culminate in true digital sovereignty.

#### Phase 1: Cross-Platform Discovery (2025)

**Current Implementation:** Basic federated discovery mechanism

* ‚Ä¢ Agents can find users across GitHub, Notion, Substack, etc.

#### Phase 2: Portable User Capabilities (2026)

* ‚Ä¢ Skills, preferences, availability sync across platforms
* ‚Ä¢ AI agents understand user capabilities universally
* ‚Ä¢ Cross-platform reputation aggregation

#### Phase 3: Direct Economic Relationships (2027)

**Creator Economy 2.0:** Direct value exchange without platform intermediation

* ‚Ä¢ AI agents broker direct economic relationships
* ‚Ä¢ Platform fees eliminated through direct discovery
* ‚Ä¢ Global talent marketplace without intermediaries

#### Phase 4: Platform-Independent Existence (2028+)

**Post-Platform Future:** Complete digital sovereignty

* ‚Ä¢ Professional identity transcends any single platform
* ‚Ä¢ AI agents work exclusively for user interests
* ‚Ä¢ Platform-independent digital existence achieved

```

}

content.html:
Why Sign MCP Feeds?

Trust Foundation for the Agent Web

The Trust Problem

Why the agent web needs cryptographic verification

üö® Without Signatures

  • ‚Ä¢ No provenance: Who really published this feed?
  • ‚Ä¢ No integrity: Has it been tampered with?
  • ‚Ä¢ No trust scoring: All feeds look identical
  • ‚Ä¢ Security risks: Agents can't verify authenticity
  • ‚Ä¢ Enterprise blockers: No audit trail or compliance

‚úÖ With Signatures

  • ‚Ä¢ Cryptographic proof: Verifiable publisher identity
  • ‚Ä¢ Tamper detection: Any modification breaks signature
  • ‚Ä¢ Trust hierarchy: Clear trust levels for agents
  • ‚Ä¢ Safe interoperability: Agents exchange feeds securely
  • ‚Ä¢ Enterprise ready: Audit trails and compliance

üìä Signed vs Unsigned: Visual Comparison

Unsigned Feed

Risky
{
  "feed_type": "mcp",
  "metadata": {
    "title": "API Service",
    "origin": "https://api.example.com"
  },
  "capabilities": [
    {
      "path": "/data",
      "method": "GET",
      "intent": "fetch_data"
    }
  ]
  // No trust block!
  // No signature!
  // No verification possible!
}

‚ö†Ô∏è Agent perspective:

  • ‚Ä¢ "Who published this?"
  • ‚Ä¢ "Is this legitimate?"
  • ‚Ä¢ "Can I trust this data?"
  • ‚Ä¢ "Has it been modified?"

Signed Feed

Trusted
{
  "feed_type": "mcp",
  "metadata": {
    "title": "API Service",
    "origin": "https://api.example.com"
  },
  "capabilities": [...],
  "trust": {
    "signed_blocks": ["metadata", "capabilities"],
    "trust_level": "certified",
    "scope": "restricted",
    "certifier": "https://llmca.org"
  },
  "signature": {
    "algorithm": "ed25519",
    "public_key_hint": "https://example.com/public.pem",
    "value": "base64-signature-value...",
    "created_at": "2025-06-19T10:30:00Z"
  }
}

‚úÖ Agent perspective:

  • ‚Ä¢ "Verified by LLMCA ‚úì"
  • ‚Ä¢ "Publisher: example.com ‚úì"
  • ‚Ä¢ "Integrity verified ‚úì"
  • ‚Ä¢ "Trust level: certified ‚úì"

üèÜ Trust Hierarchy

0

Unsigned

Anyone can publish ‚Äî no guarantee of authenticity

0%
Trust Score

Self-Signed

Feed signed by publisher's own cryptographic key

65%
Trust Score

Certified

Self-signed AND certified by recognized authority (LLMCA)

95%
Trust Score

Enterprise Certified

Full enterprise verification with SOC2, compliance audit

99%
Trust Score

üíé Why Each Feed Type Needs Signing

Feed TypeWhy Sign?Criticality
MCP
Active endpoint verification - agents must trust capabilities and API accessCritical
Credential
API access and permissions - security-critical for agent authorizationCritical
Capabilities
Tool definitions and API contracts - prevents malicious capability injectionHigh
Export
Content authenticity and source verification for agent consumptionMedium
Prompt
Trusted prompt sharing and behavioral instruction verificationMedium

üè¢ Enterprise Use Cases

Education & Professional Credentials

Challenge: Manual verification of degrees and work experience

Solution: Institutional feeds for academic and professional credentials

  • ‚Ä¢ Universities: Harvard MBA, Stanford CS degrees with GPA
  • ‚Ä¢ GAFAM: Google, Meta, Apple verify former employees
  • ‚Ä¢ AI Giants: OpenAI, Anthropic certify team alumni
  • ‚Ä¢ Instant verification for employers and recruiters
  • ‚Ä¢ Anti-fraud through tamper-proof professional records
  • ‚Ä¢ Automated background check integration

Examples:
‚Ä¢ "Jane Smith, Harvard MBA 2024, GPA 3.8, Magna Cum Laude" - hbs.edu signature
‚Ä¢ "John Doe, Senior Engineer at Google 2020-2023" - google.com signature
‚Ä¢ "Sarah Johnson, AI Researcher at OpenAI 2022-2024" - openai.com signature

Financial Services

Challenge: Regulatory compliance and audit requirements

Solution: Signed feeds provide complete audit trail

  • ‚Ä¢ SOX compliance through cryptographic verification
  • ‚Ä¢ Immutable transaction feed signatures
  • ‚Ä¢ Agent authorization with certified credentials
  • ‚Ä¢ Real-time audit trail for regulatory reporting

Healthcare

Challenge: HIPAA compliance and patient data security

Solution: Certified feeds ensure data integrity

  • ‚Ä¢ Patient data feeds with tamper-proof signatures
  • ‚Ä¢ Medical device API verification
  • ‚Ä¢ Healthcare provider credential validation
  • ‚Ä¢ Secure agent-to-agent medical data exchange

E-commerce

Challenge: Trust in automated purchasing and inventory

Solution: Verified product and pricing feeds

  • ‚Ä¢ Certified product catalog feeds
  • ‚Ä¢ Verified pricing and inventory data
  • ‚Ä¢ Secure payment processing credentials
  • ‚Ä¢ Anti-fraud through signature verification

Media & Publishing

Challenge: Content authenticity and copyright protection

Solution: Signed content feeds with provenance

  • ‚Ä¢ Verified news article feeds
  • ‚Ä¢ Copyright-protected content distribution
  • ‚Ä¢ Anti-misinformation through source verification
  • ‚Ä¢ Journalist credential and byline verification

Supply Chain

Challenge: Product authenticity and traceability verification

Solution: Manufacturer-signed product feeds

  • ‚Ä¢ Anti-counterfeiting through origin verification
  • ‚Ä¢ Supply chain transparency and tracking
  • ‚Ä¢ Quality assurance and certification feeds
  • ‚Ä¢ Automated compliance and safety verification

üîß How to Sign Your Feeds

üöÄ Option 1: Quick Start

Use LLMFeedForge

Visual builder with one-click signing

Try LLMFeedForge

Delegated Signatures

Email-verified signing for individuals

Learn Process

üíª Option 2: Developer

Self-Signing

Generate your own Ed25519 keys

Signing Guide

Validation Tools

CLI, IDE, and CI/CD integration

Explore Tools

üè¢ Option 3: Enterprise

LLMCA Certification

Third-party verification and compliance

Get Certified

SDK Integration

Programmatic signing and validation

SDK Docs

üìã Step-by-Step Signing Process

1

Generate Key Pair

Create Ed25519 public/private key pair for cryptographic signing

# Using OpenSSL
openssl genpkey -algorithm Ed25519 -out private.pem
openssl pkey -in private.pem -pubout -out public.pem
2

Structure Your Feed

Create your MCP feed with proper metadata and capabilities

Use schema validation to ensure compliance
3

Add Trust Block

Include trust metadata specifying which blocks are signed

"trust": {
  "signed_blocks": ["metadata", "capabilities"],
  "trust_level": "signed",
  "scope": "restricted"
}
4

Generate Signature

Sign the canonical JSON representation of specified blocks

See detailed signing guide for implementation
5

Publish & Serve

Deploy to /.well-known/mcp.llmfeed.json and make public key accessible

Use LLMFeedHub to test your signed feed
6

Optional: Get Certified

Request LLMCA certification for maximum trust and enterprise compliance

Certification Process

üåç The Vision: HTTPS for the Agent Web

From Chaos to Trust

Just like HTTPS transformed the web from insecure to trusted, signed MCP feeds will transform the agent web from chaotic to reliable.

üîì Before HTTPS (1990s Web)

  • ‚Ä¢ Plain text communication
  • ‚Ä¢ No identity verification
  • ‚Ä¢ Easy to intercept and modify
  • ‚Ä¢ No trust indicators
  • ‚Ä¢ Enterprise adoption blocked

üîí After HTTPS (Modern Web)

  • ‚Ä¢ Encrypted communication
  • ‚Ä¢ Certificate-based identity
  • ‚Ä¢ Tamper-proof connections
  • ‚Ä¢ Clear trust indicators (üîí)
  • ‚Ä¢ Universal enterprise adoption

üöÄ The Agent Web Future

Signed MCP feeds will become as fundamental as HTTPS certificates. Agents will automatically verify authenticity, enterprises will require signatures for compliance, and users will see clear trust indicators for AI interactions.

üöÄ Ready to Build the Trusted Agent Web?

Join thousands of developers building the next generation of AI-readable, trustworthy web infrastructure.

Start Signing Today

Get your first signed feed running in minutes

Try LLMFeedForge

Learn the Process

Master cryptographic signing and certification

Signing Guide

Join the Movement

Connect with other pioneers building the agent web

Join Community

üì§ Share This Guide

  "signed_blocks": ["metadata", "capabilities"],
  "trust_level": "signed",
  "scope": "restricted"
}
```

4

### Generate Signature

Sign the canonical JSON representation of specified blocks

See [detailed signing guide](/tools/sign-and-verify) for implementation

5

### Publish & Serve

Deploy to /.well-known/mcp.llmfeed.json and make public key accessible

Use [LLMFeedHub](/llmfeedhub) to test your signed feed

6

### Optional: Get Certified

Request LLMCA certification for maximum trust and enterprise compliance

[Certification Process](/tools/certification-process)

## üåç The Vision: HTTPS for the Agent Web

### From Chaos to Trust

Just like HTTPS transformed the web from insecure to trusted, signed MCP feeds will transform the agent web from chaotic to reliable.

#### üîì Before HTTPS (1990s Web)

* ‚Ä¢ Plain text communication
* ‚Ä¢ No identity verification
* ‚Ä¢ Easy to intercept and modify
* ‚Ä¢ No trust indicators
* ‚Ä¢ Enterprise adoption blocked

#### üîí After HTTPS (Modern Web)

* ‚Ä¢ Encrypted communication
* ‚Ä¢ Certificate-based identity
* ‚Ä¢ Tamper-proof connections
* ‚Ä¢ Clear trust indicators (üîí)
* ‚Ä¢ Universal enterprise adoption

#### üöÄ The Agent Web Future

Signed MCP feeds will become as fundamental as HTTPS certificates. Agents will automatically verify authenticity, enterprises will require signatures for compliance, and users will see clear trust indicators for AI interactions.

## üöÄ Ready to Build the Trusted Agent Web?

Join thousands of developers building the next generation of AI-readable, trustworthy web infrastructure.

### Start Signing Today

Get your first signed feed running in minutes

[Try LLMFeedForge](https://llmfeedforge.org)

### Learn the Process

Master cryptographic signing and certification

[Signing Guide](/tools/sign-and-verify)

### Join the Movement

Connect with other pioneers building the agent web

[Join Community](/join)

## üì§ Share This Guide

[X](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Why%20Sign%20MCP%20Feeds%3F%20-%20Trust%20Foundation%20for%20the%20Agent%20Web&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwellknownmcp.org%2Fwhy-sign&hashtags=MCPSigning%2CAgentWeb%2CTrust%2CSecurity%2CAI "Share on X with hashtags: MCPSigning, AgentWeb, Trust, Security, AI")[LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwellknownmcp.org%2Fwhy-sign&title=Why%20Sign%20MCP%20Feeds%3F%20-%20Trust%20Foundation%20for%20the%20Agent%20Web "Share on LinkedIn")[WhatsApp](https://wa.me/?text=Why%20Sign%20MCP%20Feeds%3F%20-%20Trust%20Foundation%20for%20the%20Agent%20Web%20https%3A%2F%2Fwellknownmcp.org%2Fwhy-sign "Share on WhatsApp")Copy link

LLMFeed SDK & Tools

Use our open tools to build, sign and interact with agent-readable feeds

NEW

Everything you need to generate, validate, transform, and certify LLMFeed blocks. Explore our SDKs and scripts or connect to the API.

üöÄ Quick Start

NPM: npm install @wellknownmcp/client
CDN: https://cdn.wellknownmcp.org/client.min.js
‚Üí Complete Documentation

üõ†Ô∏è Core SDK & API Tools

  • Sign & Verify:Python & TypeScript scripts for cryptographic validation
  • Canonicalization: Normalize feeds for consistent signature payloads
  • Export Button:Drop-in React component to expose `.llmfeed.json` from any page
  • Forge API: Programmatic access to build & sign feeds viallmfeedforge.org

Code Example

import { validateFeed, signFeed } from '@wellknownmcp/client';

const feed = {
  feed_type: "export",
  metadata: { title: "My Content", origin: "https://example.com" }
};

const isValid = validateFeed(feed);
const signed = await signFeed(feed, { keyPath: './private.pem' });

üöÄ Strategic SDK Extensions (Coming Soon)

1. üß† Agent Store & Reputation Graph

A decentralized directory of agent profiles and compatible services. Powered by signed agent-profile.llmfeed.json and certification scores by llmca.org. Includes search, trust filters, and flagging mechanisms.

2. üåê Gateway SDKs for the Old Web

Wrappers and plugins for WordPress, Shopify, GraphQL or HTML APIs to auto-generate LLMFeed-compatible blocks. Accelerates compatibility for non-native services.

3. üß© LLMFeed Browser Extension

A lightweight extension that detects .well-known feeds, enables agent interactions, and lets users preview agent-readable metadata.

4. üì§ LLMFeed Exporter Extension

A browser plugin that captures any web page and builds a downloadable `.llmfeed.json`. Perfect for fast sharing to agents ‚Äî even without a server or signature.

These components will turn LLMFeed into a full stack: discovery, interaction, monetization, trust.
